title: Dangers of poor sleep, Alzheimer’s risk, mental health, and memory
content: Matthew Walker, professor of neuroscience at UC Berkeley and expert on sleep, describes the different stages, and cycles, of sleep, including what he calls the 4 pillars of sleep, and how they contribute to memory consolidation and numerous important pathways to mental health. We also get into the dangers of chronic sleep deprivation, such as the development of dementia, and the more acute dangers of sleep deprivation like fatal car crashes which are most often caused by drowsy driving. We also discuss the different and important roles of REM vs. non-REM sleep, and the impact that bad sleep habits can have specifically on those sleep stages.

title: Matthew's background and interest in sleep
content: Matthew's background and interest in sleep [5:00]. Instead, he got undergrad in neuroscience at University of Nottingham. Then got Ph.D. at Newcastle University and his research was funded by the Medical Research Council in London. Went to Harvard for faculty position in psychiatry, there for 7 years – did not like winter or combative/competitive environment at Harvard. Came to Berkeley, has been there since.

title: Sleep and Alzheimer’s disease, and the 4 pillars of sleep
content: Sleep and Alzheimer’s disease, and the 4 pillars of sleep [11:15]. Could sleep disruption be a biomarker of dementia, or even an underlying cause? Could poor sleep lead to neuronal energy deprivation (like vascular disease and insulin resistance)? Sleep impacts oxidative stress. From Matthew’s book: “Wakefulness is low level brain damage” and “sleep is the price we pay for wakefulness”. It’s a tenable hypothesis that evolutionarily, sleep may have been the default state ⇒ “Perhaps the default state of life on the planet was sleep, and it was from sleep that wakefulness emerged.”

title: Alzheimer’s disease
content: Alzheimer’s disease. The first thing is that we see that within insufficient sleep, you get increases in oxidative stress and that leads to a whole cascade of things that lead to neuronal death. Hippocampus (memory) 1st damaged in Alzheimer’s (forgetfulness). ⇒ Remarkable discovery: In 2012, Rochester University team found that brain has “sewage” system (glymphatic system, glial cells) similar to lymphatic system. Sanitation system that kicks in when in deep sleep and glial cells shrink up to 200% in size make room for cerebral spinal fluid fill brain and wash out “metabolic detritus” of wakefulness. How is this related to AD? β-amyloid is one of things washed away, a core protein in Alzheimer’s formation which escalates Alzheimer’s risk.

title: The role of β-amyloid in AD
content: The role of β-amyloid in AD may not be the main causal driver, but if sleep is more about clearance than generation, it is congruent with the idea that other things on the back end are driving it primarily. Alzheimer’s is so complicated because of genetic predisposition + multiple pathways driving injury to a very sensitive organ.

title: Tau and AD
content: Data is better for tau predicting cognitive decline. Tau accumulation can also result from sleep insufficiency. The fact that sleep is a strong predictor for this risk means links between insufficient sleep and this heterogeneous disease are quite strong.

title: The future of subtypes and AD
content: When we eventually subtype Alzheimer’s, we will likely find that subsets of sleep features are linked to subsets of Alzheimer’s. For example, deep sleep deprivation predictive of one subtype, sleep fragmentation predictive of another.

title: The 4 Pillars of Sleep
content: The 4 pillars of sleep are regularity, continuity, quantity, and quality. Alzheimer’s is very complex: Different sleep features will be predictive of different aspects of the amyloid pathology cascade.

title: Matthew’s upcoming paper
content: Matthew’s upcoming paper will bucket people into ten-year periods based on quantity and quality of sleep, then map β-amyloid and tau in the brain late in life. The question is whether sleep at certain decades is more critical at predicting these levels.

title: β vs. tau
content: Sleep deprivation in different decades seems to be linked to an increase in β vs. tau. β-amyloid is a strong predictive signal in the 30s and 40s, then again in the 60s and 70s. Tau is a strong predictive signal in the 50s and 60s through 80s. β-amyloid is bimodal, and it seems that general memory bias would not explain this.

title: The failure of pharmacological approach to β-amyloid reduction
content: The failure rate of amyloid antibody as a treatment for AD 99.6%

title: Sleep and its effects on health
content: Poor sleep affects CVD, which affects brain; glucose disposal also affects brain. Sleep deprivation therefore has many confounders so it would be hard to tease out mechanistic links. Matthew gives himself a 'non-negotiable' 8 hours of sleep per night. His family has a history of CVD ⇒ 'we know that deep sleep is probably the best form of blood pressure medication that you could ever wish for.'

title: Focusing on prevention of AD
content: Since there are no robust pharmaceutical treatments for Alzheimer’s yet, the focus is shifting towards early stage prevention. One of best preventative actions is to 'capitalize on' sleep at night. Matthew says that one of the best preventative actions that you can take on the basis of the science right now, is start to capitalize on your sleep at night.

title: Stages of sleep, sleep cycles, and brainwaves
content: Humans (Mammals) have 2 stages: Non-REM and REM. Non-REM has 4 stages: Cleverly titled=Stages 1, 2, 3, and 4. Stages 3 and 4 are the very deep restorative stages. Stages 1 and 2 are the lightest stages of sleep. REM sleep: (REM=Rapid eye movement, based on the bizarre horizontal shifting eye movements). 90 minute sleep cycles. Every 90 minutes, your brain cycles between non-REM and REM sleep. Then this is replayed every 90 minutes to create what we call a standard cycling architecture of sleep, or what we call a hypnogram of sleep. Brainwaves when first lie down (before you fall asleep): Alpha rhythm. Theta waves begin in stage 1. In stage 2, synchronous bursts of electrical activity called sleep spindles (a second and half long) ⇒ Big slow wave, then burst of spindle. Then stages 3 and 4: Brain in synchronous chant of slow waves. 1 or 2 cycles per second, but size of waves are huge.

title: The 90 Minute Sleep Cycle
content: The 90 minute sleep cycle consists of going through stage 1-4 on non-REM, then after 70 min, you go back to stage 2 on non-REM, then you will briefly transition to REM sleep, then you flip flop between non-REM and REM ⇒ back down into non-REM, back to REM, back to non-REM, and the ratio of non-REM to REM changes as you move across the night. In the first half of the night, the majority of the 90 minute cycle is deep non-REM, and in the second half of the night, the majority of the cycle is REM. If you get 6 hours sleep (instead of 8), you’re losing 25% of sleep, but could be losing up to 70% of all REM sleep.

title: The Architecture of Sleep
content: Different types of memory rely on different stages of sleep at different times of night. Deep non-REM sleep (stage 3 and 4) protects new learning from the day before, and you need sleep after learning to essentially hit the save button on new memories so that you don’t forget. Stage 2 of non-REM refreshes and prepares your brain for future learning and memory. REM sleep seems to recalibrate emotional networks in the brain (middle part of prefrontal cortex and amygdala).

title: The Detriment of Reduced REM Sleep
content: The biggest detriment that persons face clinically with the reduction of REM is increased mental health issues such as anxiety, depression, and suicidality. In young teens, the strongest predictor of suicidal ideation, attempts, and completion is insufficient sleep. REM sleep seems to recalibrate emotional networks in the brain (middle part of prefrontal cortex and amygdala).

title: Evolutionary Reasons to Sleep
content: Sleep has become stigmatized as laziness and sloth. In 70 years, we’ve lost 20-25% sleep. By comparison, imagine a reduction in O2 saturation by 20-25% (It’s very clear that’s not a good idea.)

title: Peter's Personal Story About His Attitude Towards Sleep
content: Peter resisted lots of sleep until about 2012. During med school, he spent about 114 hrs per week working in the hospital and got about 28 hours of sleep a week.

title: Sleep is the foundation of health
content:
“Sleep is the greatest life support system you could ever wish for. It’s a remarkable health insurance policy, it’s largely democratic, free and largely painless.”
Sleep is the foundation of health

In terms of de-risking just about every disease that is killing us in the developed world, it’s very hard to look no further than sleep
Nutrition and exercise are important, but sleep in the foundation
“Sleep is the foundation on which those two other things sit. It’s not the third pillar of good health, I think it is the foundation.”

title: The dangers of sleep deprivation
content:
Deprivation of sleep causes the quickest reduction of health
Guinness has banned trying to set record for sleep deprivation (record might have been up to 24 days) because it’s so dangerous (cancer, mental health, CVD, metabolic syndrome, suicidality).
Think about this: 

Felix Baumgartner went up in hot air balloon to outer surface of Earth and then jumped out, fell over 1000/km/hr, broke sound barrier
That was NOT banned by Guinness, but sleep deprivation was – gives you sense of how dangerous it is not to sleep

title: Tips for overcoming jet lag
content:
Early riser vs. the night owl, and tips for overcoming jet lag [1:09:15]
What is different about 2 people who both only sleep for 6 hours, but one person from 9 pm – 3 am and the other midnight to 6 am?

Jet lag and changing time zones:

Example, if flying from California to London… 

Wake up 10 min earlier for 5 days before, then very early on flight day
Sleep on first half of flight (not second as many people do) to line up what the people are doing in London
Build up “sleep pressure” so can sleep when night in London (the longer you are awake, the more you will build up sleep pressure)

In example above, type of sleep you get will not be the same ⇒ if move your window of sleep to earlier in the day (short changing REM sleep) or to later in the night (short changing deep non-REM)

Peter’s observations of sleep when flip flopping between CA and NY

When in NY: Trying to stay on CA time ⇒ Going to bed later, waking up later
When in CA: very early sleeper and an early riser
Tries to stick to 8 hours

Can do that very well in California
Not as well in New York


First night back in California, he has much higher amount of deep sleep

“And that would explain it. It’s this phase shift that I’m capturing.”
Just came back from New York last night (so now in CA), went to bed at 8:30 p.m., and got up at 5 am, but had a huge deep sleep


⇒ Matthew’s reaction: 

“Exactly, so you dragged your eight-hour window.”
“If you think about this sort of eight-hour window, and you slide it back on the clock face from midnight, to 11 p.m., to 10 p.m., to in fact, 9 p.m., you’re dragging that eight-hour sleep phase back, closer into the deep sleep-rich phase, the deep non-REM sleep that you want. . .And perhaps, you may actually see a little bit of a reduction in REM sleep.”
“As you go to New York, you may see the opposite.”

title: The Importance of Sleep
content: Matthew's book discusses the erosion of sleep time, which has hit an all-time high. In 1942, the average person slept 7.9 hours per night, but today, the average person sleeps 6 hours and 31 minutes. The decline has not been linear, it is accelerating. There is no physiological system in the body, and there is no operation of the brain that isn’t wonderfully enhanced by sleep when you get it, or demonstrably impaired when you don’t get enough.

title: The Perfect Storm
content: Matthew says we have reached the perfect storm: the collision between increasing sleep deprivation and increasing sickness and disease that we’ve almost never seen before.
